Package com.behreajj.camzup.friendly

Class UpOgl

java.lang.Object
processing.core.PImage
processing.core.PGraphics
processing.opengl.PGraphicsOpenGL
com.behreajj.camzup.friendly.UpOgl
All Implemented Interfaces:
IUp, IUpOgl, Cloneable, processing.core.PConstants
Direct Known Subclasses:
Up3, Yup2
public abstract class UpOgl extends processing.opengl.PGraphicsOpenGL implements IUpOgl
An abstract parent class for Processing renderers based on OpenGL.

  • Nested Class Summary

    • bezierPoint

      public float bezierPoint(float ap0, float cp0, float cp1, float ap1, float t)
      Evaluates a BÃ©zier curve at step t for points ap0, cp0, cp1 and ap1. The parameter t varies between [0.0, 1.0]; ap0 and ap1 are the curve's anchor points; cp0 and cp1 the control points. This can be done once with the x coordinates and a second time with the y coordinates to get the location of a BÃ©zier curve at t.
      Overrides:
      bezierPoint in class processing.core.PGraphics
      Parameters:
      ap0 - the first anchor point
      cp0 - the first control point
      cp1 - the second control point
      ap1 - the second anchor point
      t - the step

    • colorMode

      public void colorMode(int mode, float max1, float max2, float max3, float aMax)
      Sets the renderer's color mode. Color channel maximums should be within the range [1.0f, 1000.0f] to mitigate precision issues arising from conversion between single precision real numbers and colors stored in 32-bit integers with [0, 255] per channel.
      Overrides:
      colorMode in class processing.core.PGraphics
      Parameters:
      mode - the color mode, HSB or RGB
      max1 - the first channel maximum, hue or red
      max2 - the second channel maximum, saturation or green
      max3 - the third channel maximum, brightness or blue
      aMax - the alpha channel maximum

    • disableDepthMask

      public void disableDepthMask()
      Attempts to make the hint system more convenient to work with. From the reference:

      Disables writing into the depth buffer. This means that a shape drawn with this hint can be hidden by another shape drawn later, irrespective of their distances to the camera. Note that this is different from disabling the depth test. The depth test is still applied, as long as the DISABLE_DEPTH_TEST hint is not called, but the depth values of the objects are not recorded.

    • disableDepthTest

      public void disableDepthTest()
      Attempts to make the hint system more convenient to work with. From the reference:

      Disable the z buffer, allowing you to draw on top of everything at will. When depth testing is disabled, items will be drawn to the screen sequentially, like a painting. When called, this will also clear the depth buffer.

    • disableMipMaps

      public void disableMipMaps()
      Attempts to make the hint system more convenient to work with. From the reference:

      Disable generation of texture mipmaps in P2D or P3D. This results in lower quality - but faster - rendering of texture images when they appear smaller than their native resolutions (the mipmaps are scaled-down versions of a texture that make it look better when drawing it at a small size). However, the difference in performance is fairly minor on recent desktop video cards.

    • disableOptimizedStroke

      public void disableOptimizedStroke()
      Attempts to make the hint system more convenient to work with. From the reference:

      Forces the P3D renderer to draw each shape (including its strokes) separately, instead of batching them into larger groups for better performance. One consequence of this is that 2D items drawn with P3D are correctly stacked on the screen, depending on the order in which they were drawn. Otherwise, glitches such as the stroke lines being drawn on top of the interior of all the shapes will occur. However, this hint can make rendering substantially slower, so it is recommended to use it only when drawing a small amount of shapes.

      protected void colorCalc(int argb)
      Calculates a color from an integer. Does not attempt to detect difference between an 8-bit gray color integer and a 32-bit ARGB hexadecimal, e.g., between fill(128); and fill(0xff808080);.
      Overrides:

      Parameters:

    • colorCalcARGB

      protected void colorCalcARGB(int rgb, float alpha)
      Calculates a color from an integer and alpha value. Useful in the IDE for colors defined with hashtag literals, such as "#aabbcc" .

      Does not attempt to detect difference between an 8-bit gray color integer and a 32-bit ARGB hexadecimal, e.g., between fill(128, 255); and fill(#808080, 255);.
      Overrides:
      colorCalcARGB in class processing.core.PGraphics
      Parameters:
      rgb - the hexadecimal color
      alpha - the alpha channel

    • model

      protected Vec3 model(float xSource, float ySource, float zSource, Vec3 target)
      Internal helper to public functions for 2.5D and 3D. Finds the position of a point in the model view. Does so by
      1. promoting the point to a vector 4, where its w component is 1.0 .
      2. multiplying the vector 4 by the model view matrix;
      3. multiplying the product by the camera inverse;
      4. demoting the vector 4 to a point 3 by dividing the x, y and z components by w.
      More efficient than calling PApplet.modelX(float, float, float) , PApplet.modelY(float, float, float) and PApplet.modelZ(float, float, float) separately. However, it is advisable to work with Vec4s and the renderer matrices directly.
      Parameters:
      xSource - the source x
      ySource - the source y
      zSource - the source z
      target - the output point
      Returns:
      the model space point

    • noLightAmbient

      protected void noLightAmbient(int num)

    • screen

      protected Vec3 screen(float xSource, float ySource, float zSource, Vec3 target)
      Internal helper to public functions for 2.5D and 3D. Finds the screen position of a point in the world. Does so by
      1. promoting the point to a vector 4, where its w component is 1.0 .
      2. multiplying the vector 4 by the model view matrix;
      3. multiplying the product by the projection;
      4. demoting the vector 4 to a point 3 by dividing the x, y and z components by w;
      5. flipping the y axis;
      6. shifting the range from [-1.0, 1.0] to [(0.0, 0.0), (width, height)] .
      More efficient than calling PApplet.screenX(float, float, float) , PApplet.screenY(float, float, float) , and PApplet.screenZ(float, float, float) separately. However, it is advisable to work with Vec4s and the renderer matrices directly.
      Parameters:
      xSource - the source x
      ySource - the source y
      zSource - the source z
      target - the output vector
      Returns:
      the screen point

    • screen1s

      protected Vec3 screen1s(float xSource, float ySource, float zSource, Vec3 target)
      An internal helper function that multiplies the input point by the model view, then by the projection.
      Parameters:
      xSource - the source x
      ySource - the source y
      zSource - the source z
      target - the output vector
      Returns:
      the screen point

    • vertexTexture

      protected void vertexTexture(float u, float v)
      Updates the texture coordinates of the renderer. If the texture mode is IMAGE, divides the UV coordinates by the image's dimensions. If the texture wrap is CLAMP, clamps the coordinates to [0.0, 1.0]. If the wrap is REPEAT, floor wraps them instead.
      Overrides:
      vertexTexture in class processing.core.PGraphics
      Parameters:
      u - the s or u coordinate
      v - the t or v coordinate

    • vertexTexture

      protected void vertexTexture(float u, float v, int desiredTextureMode, int desiredTextureWrap)
      Updates the texture coordinates of the renderer. If the texture mode is IMAGE, divides the UV coordinates by the image's dimensions. If the texture wrap is CLAMP, clamps the coordinates to [0.0, 1.0]. If the wrap is REPEAT, wraps them instead.
      Parameters:
      u - the s or u coordinate
      v - the t or v coordinate
      desiredTextureMode - the texture mode, IMAGE or NORMAL
      desiredTextureWrap - the texture wrap, CLAMP or REPEAT
      See Also:
      • Utils.div(float, float)
      • Utils.clamp01(float)
